summary.seg: This manuscript contains a large number of medical treatises, and medical recipes alongside instructions of a magical, cosmetic, practical, equestrian, and horticultural nature.

The collection also a previously unidentified selection of recipes from the Treatises of fistula in ano: haemorrhoids, and clysters by the London surgeon John Arderne (1307–1392) on pp. 156-160. An adaptation made to one of Arderne's recipes on p. 160, called a 'Valence of Wormwood', may give an insight into the scribe's background. Arderne's original version reports how the surgeon used this medicine to heal a fisherman from London who had injured his arm on a sharp iron attached to the door of the monastery of the Carmelites or White Friars [see D'Arcy Power (1910), pp. 100, 133-134]. However, the version in Pepys MS 878 has been updated with what appears to be another medical practitioner's testimony: This medicine I have often used and praised because with it I healed a sheriff at Bristol who endured a puncture wound in the muscle of his left arm from a small dagger while separating two (fighting) men and he was close to death because of the pain, swelling, burning, and cramp caused by a miserable cure from a barber-surgeon who put tight rolls of linen in the wound and put diachylon on top of it. I removed his cure and replaced it with 'Valence of Wormwood' and 'Sanguis Verenis' and God healed him shortly after that - in accordance with William Elmeden [Elmedon] and the mayor of Rockingham ['þis I have mekyll vsed and loued for with it I helyd a shirreff at Bristowe þe which of þe prikyng of a small dagger poynt as he departyd .ij. men in the lacert of is lyfte arme almost for payn bolnyng and brynnyng and crampe was ny dede thorow an onappy cure of a barbowre þe which putte harde tentys of lyne in þe wounde and layde diaculium layde aboue is cure put a way valcen sanguis verenis putte in a lityll while god helyd hym. With þis cure god helyd. Secundum Wylliam Elmedene and þe mayre of Rokyngham'].

The account has previously been largely missed. McKitterick and Beadle expand 'S. Wylliam Elmedene' to 'Ser Wylliam Elmedene' and suggest that William Elmeden was a patient (see McKitterick and Beadle (1992), p. 5). However, it is possible that William Elmeden - perhaps Sir William de Elmedon (1381-1447), Lord of Elmedon, of Embleton, Durham, or his son William Elmedon (b. 1417) - testified to the medicine's efficacy as a medical practitioner instead. The same may apply to the unnamed mayor of Rockingham, Northamptonshire, to whose testimony the text also refers. This could be suggestive of the milieu in and for which the manuscript was copied; one in which non-university trained healers shared information about medical treatments with one another.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

msContents.textLang: Middle English, with dialectal features that are locatable to East Anglia [see McKitterick and Beadle (1992), p. 5]

msItem.title: The Wise Book of Astronomy and Philosophy
msItem.rubric: 1 Her begynnyth þe wyse boke of philosophye and after conteyned and made of þe wysest philosophur and astronemo þat euer was seth þe world was frist [sic] be goun þat is so say of þe lond of grece ffor in þat lond an Englysch man ffulwis was and wel vnderstandyng of philosophie and astronome stodied and compyled þis boke out of grewe in to Englysche graciously
msItem.incipit: 1 Fyrst þis boke tellyth how many heuenys þer ben aftyrward he pronounsed and declareth of þe cowrs and of þe gouernaunce of þe planetis aftryward of þe syngnes and þe sterres of þe firmament aftyrward of þe elementis and complexcyons and þe maner of man without weche scyense and knowyng no man may cum to perfyte worchyng of astronomye ne philosofie ne surgerie ne of non othur sotyll scyence
msItem.explicit: 37 who so vseþe te ete .iij. leues of sage or a pepyrcorne eche day he schal not drede þe palsye noþer þe rynnyng gowte

msItem.title: The Book of Destinary
msItem.incipit: 16 Nowe it is for to declare and determyne of þe xij sygnes and of her kyndez wat euery man is ordeynyd be way of kynd and predestinacioun
msItem.explicit: 34 she shcal lyue an .C. ȝere here gode dayes ben monday þursday and fryday and wednysday saterday ben euyll

msItem.title: Lucky and unlucky days for bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 34 And it is to wete þat who wil perfytlye þe lif and predesteniacioun of man be þese forsayde .xij. sygnes .vij. planetes and iiij. Elementes him be howiþ to be hold and folowe þe perilous timys of þe kalender and trewly and perfytely he may ȝeue þer of a dome
msItem.incipit: 34 But who so wil lerne of þe mone vnderstond wel þat on þe first is iij. mondays and clerkys seyn þat þei be waried on þe whech no man lete hym blode of wound noþer o veyne
msItem.explicit: 35 þese forsayde dayes ben þe perlous days in þe mone and þe gode aclep þe canyculer dayes þat ken tel you byfore on þe boke as þe kalendour makeþ mencyuun and after þe fest of þe [?sterr]

msItem.title: Prophecies of Esdras
msItem.incipit: 35 Esdras þe prophete doþ us to wete þat þer beþ .xxxij. dayes in þe ȝer perlous in þe whech a man or womman falleþ in syknesse
msItem.explicit: 37 who so vseþe te ete .iij. leues of sage or a pepyrcorne eche day he schal not drede þe palsye noþer þe rynnyng gowte

msItem.title: Uroscopic treatise ['Urine Brown with a Black Ring']
msItem.incipit: 39 Uryne brovne with a blacke rynge is syngne of deth
msItem.explicit: 54 Now vndirstond þis rewle mortificacioun is as moche to seyne as for doyng of kyndly hete

msItem.title: Collection of medical, magical, cosmetical, gynaecological and household recipes
msItem.incipit: 54-55 ffor þe morfu: Take an vnce of vergrece and a oþer of quyck b[r]ymston and make hem boþe in powdir and þan take j. schepis hedis and take out þe brayne and seeþ þe hedis till þey ben tendre and cole hem and gedir þe greswe and menge it with powdir an anoynte þe þerwith and it schal make þe hole
msItem.explicit: 107 On oþer for alle gutes. Take nien dayes . inen þe leste leues þat mist finde of blake þistel and of wylde þistel and hete fastinde þanne take herbeine and planteyne and seth hem wel in rede wyn and drinc amoruen cold and an euen hoth
msItem.note:
The collection mostly concerns medical recipes but ends with different types of recipes, including:
Magical recipes (p. 102), including methods to obtain a woman's secrets by placing an amber or jet stone on her body during sleep and to prevent a goose's chickens from dying by giving them water to drink in which bread or parchment inscribed with the Lord's Prayer has been washed.
Gynaecological recipes (pp. 103-104), including methods to help a couple become pregnant, a method for establishing whether the cause for unwanted childlessness in a couple lies with the man or the woman, and methods for establishing the sex of an unborn child.
Cosmetic recipes (pp. 103-104), including methods to dye hair black and blond ('gold') and remove blemishes.
Repellants (pp. 102-103, 105), including methods to stop dogs from barking at you, drive flies out of a house, and keep wolves from a piece of land.
Household/Practical recipes (pp. 105-106), including methods to open a silver ring by adding mercury to it and join to pieces of meat together.
Equestrian medicine (p. 105-106), including recipes for healing ailments in horses.
Horticultural instructions (p. 107), including methods for harvesting grapes and cherries all year round.

McKitterick and Beadle (1992), p. 3, point out that many of the recipes on pp. 59-107 also appear in a collection of recipes in Lincoln, Cathedral Library, MS 91 [The Lincoln Thornton Manuscript], entitled 'Liber de diversis medicinis' but this is not the case for most of the specified non-medical recipes.

The collection contains a previously unidentified selection of recipes from John Arderne's Treatises of fistula in ano : haemorrhoids, and clysters: 'Sanguis veneris' (pp. 156-157; 'Valens of Scabius' (pp. 158-159); 'Valence of Wourmot' (pp. 159-160).

msItem.title: Charm against the hiccup
msItem.incipit: 68 Sey . kyrieleison. Christe eleison . Kyerieleson and hold þy hed vpwarde and þi honde by fore þey þrote and holde so þi breȝth inne . also longe ast þou mayst
msItem.note: The recipe that precedes the charm instructs the patient to hold both hands in holy water.

msItem.title: Uroscopic tract
msItem.incipit: 108 Omnis vrina est colamentum sanguinis
msItem.explicit: 113 si moribus nascitur placientes pleni indentur
msItem.note: Latin version of the Middle English text on pp. 183–188.

msItem.title: Alphabetical list of medical ingredients
msItem.incipit: 113 Ambra / Acacia / Agarica
msItem.explicit: 116 Zucare .bi. li. 1. s. / Zinzibere alexandrium .li. 12. d. / Zinzibere conditum .li. 2. s.

msItem.title: List of oils and unguents
msItem.incipit: 116 Olea calida sunt / Oleum laurinum / Oleum missellinum / Oleum anatilion
msItem.explicit: 118 Pro quartana. / Musa enea. / Adrianum pocio

msItem.title: Tract on the properties of oil
msItem.textLang: Latin with some Middle English words
msItem.incipit: 118 Oleum de tertero accipe de illo et pulueriza et in funde in aceto
msItem.explicit: 121 R. de eo sero et mano
msItem.note: The tract is written in Latin but some recipes include English terms for ingredients, including: 'figys', 'raysynys', 'herb yve' (p. 121.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 121 For hed warke betan veruan wormod camamil et fenel ana [ounce] 1
msItem.explicit: 125 ffor zeskyns drynk: þe ius of sawge with stale ale at moren cold at ewyn hot

msItem.title: Recipe for making gingerbread
msItem.incipit: 124 ffor gynge bred take quartes of hony and seet yt and styr yt to yt be wax tycke and þen take yt downe and put it in a wet wesayl and put þerto a pund of powdyr of gyngar and a quartrun of powdir of peper and ster al wele togedere and seet yt a lytyl ouer þe fir and styrre yt wele and þen draw yt to yt be cold and kep yt

msItem.title: Recipe for making a dish of quinces and pears
msItem.incipit: 124-125 ffor schard coynys tak a wart of hony and clarefy yt and put þerto [ounce] j of pepyr and tak xxx coynys and x wardonis and schet þem in wyne or ale and ye stampe þem and streye þem in to þe hony and þen boyle þem to þei be thyk and ay be ster and and [sic] þen take yt down and do þerto [ounce] j of powdir of gyngar and galiga and canel ana [ounce] j and mel al togydere and kep yt ffor scharde wardune tak .xxx. wardownys and x coynys and make os yt ys be forsayd

msItem.title: Recipe for making Aqua Vite
msItem.incipit: 125 Aqua uite perfectissima recipe ollivam terram et impleatur usque ad medium bono vino rube
msItem.explicit: 125 Ista aqua assimulatur balsamo naturali que habet omnipotens eius virtutes

msItem.title: Recipe for a panacea
msItem.incipit: 125 Custodit carnes et pisces relentes et cok[u]at suis naturis et sibi subtrahit omnes dulcedines omni specierum et radicium in ea coktarum et valet in omnibus infrimitatibus frigidis et pro paralise et gutta frigida ad neruos retractos et custodit omnes sanitates infra corpus humanum et dat bonum appetitum et clarificat visum destruam carnem mortuam de wlneribus et mortificat fistulam et cancrum et wlt ardere super omnem rem sine lesione et verum et multos alijs

msItem.title: Magical uses for powder from a snake's heart
msItem.incipit: 125-126 Cum luna fuerit amentando in primo gradu signi geminorum pulueriza cor serpentis in isto modo calefac duos lapides in igne ut rubeus sint et tunc inter pone cor serpentis et sic ardetur et puluerizetur et vsui reseruetur
msItem.explicit: 126 Et si quis timiat de veneno sciat quacumque fuerit appositum totum dispergetur. Et si quis super se gerat erit inuisibilis et omnibus amabilis
msItem.note: The text explains how to make powder from a snake's heart and use it to heal all wounds, become invulnerableto injuries, heal leprosy, make foes flee and gain the affection and help of friends, become appointed, identify thieves and stolen objects, become invulnerable to poison, become invisible, and loved by all.

msItem.title: Note on the celestial bodies and their elements
msItem.incipit: 126 Aries est de naturaa de igne
msItem.explicit: 126 Saturnus de mercurio

msItem.title: Unlucky days for medicine
msItem.incipit: 126 Notandum est hic de diebus infortunatis et malis quorum in anuo sunt 33
msItem.explicit: 126December habet 3a 6. 2. 17. et fleobotometur quod bonum est

msItem.title: Herbal
msItem.incipit: 127 De calidis in primo gradu absinthium
msItem.explicit: 133 Testudines / De potibus / Nix

msItem.title: Dictionary of medicinal ingredients
msItem.incipit: 133 Aloen succus est herbe calidus est in 2o gradu uirtute habet purgandi coleram et fleminam et melancoliam
msItem.explicit: 151 Zucarum calidum et humidum temperate nassitur in canna virtutem habet humectandi infrigiandi nutriendi et relaxendi

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 152 ffor the migryine: Take wex and rosyll ffrankensens mastike gumme edere terpontine galbanum evene portioun and take oyle of olyue poudere of linsed pouder of anneys comyne fenel sede bays of lorey euene portioun melte hem alle to gedere and make a cappe of ledere and ley this thynge there onne and take lyne cloth and ley there abowe and poyne itt well to gedere and do it on thyne hedde and þat will laste .xx. ȝere
msItem.explicit: 170 Now vnderstand þat þis oytement makes good skynne in two nyghtis and hit elys sunbrennyng chynnes and ragatiffes and sissurus [sic: ? 'fissures'] on hand hips and al oþer membres for þis oytement may no good Siyu[r]g[ien] want þer for hawe it in reuerence
msItem.note: The collection features recipes for a previously unidentified selection of recipes from John Arderne's Treatises of fistula in ano : haemorrhoids, and clysters 'Sanguis veneris' (pp. 156-157; 'Valens of Scabius' (pp. 158-159); 'Valence of Wourmot' (pp. 159-160); In his recipe for a 'Valence of wormod', Arderne reports how he used the medicine to heal a fisherman from London who had injured his arm on a sharp iron near the monastery of the Carmelites. However, the version in Pepys MS 878 has been updated with what appear to be another physician's testimonies. This physician states that 'this medicine I have often used and praised because with it I healed a sheriff at Bristol who endured a puncture wound in the muscle of his left arm from a small dagger as he separated two (fighting) men and was close to death because of the pain, swelling, burning, and cramp and because a miserable cure from a barber who put tight rolls of linen in the wound and put diachylon on top of it. I removed his cure and replaced it with 'valence of wormwood' and 'sanguis verenis' and God healed him shortly after that - according to the practice of William Elmeden [Elmedon] and the mayor of Rockingham.' ['þis I have mekyll vsed and loued for with it I helyd a shirreff at Bristowe þe which of þe prikyng of a small dagger poynt as he departyd .ij. men in the lacert of is lyfte arme almost for payn bolnyng and brynnyng and crampe was ny dede thorow an onappy cure of a barbowre þe which putte harde tentys of lyne in þe wounde and layde diaculium layde aboue is cure put a way valcen sanguis verenis putte in a lityll while god helyd hym. With þis cure god helyd. Secundum Wylliam Elmeden and þe mayre of Rokyngham'].

msItem.title: Charm to heal a wound
msItem.rubric: 154 to hele iche maner of wounde
msItem.incipit: 154-155 By a plate of lede it schal not fester ne cancre whil þe plat lith þer. Tys maner þe plat be mad + and bles it wil þou makeste it an whan þou makist þe Croyse say .v. Pater noster in þe worchep of owrlord Jhesu and after say þis vers. Wlnera quinque dei sint medicina mei / Sunt Medicina tui pia crux et passio Christi. And after þis say Jhesu as sothly as þu suffirdest .v. woundes in þi precius body for all sinneres so sothly hele þou þis man þi serwant of þis malendye and of all oþer malodyes in þe worchep of þe fader and sone and þe holy gost amen pater noster. v. syȝes and war wele þat þe plate touche not þe erþe aftir þe blessyng and remewe þe plate iij. tymes in þe day and wasche it in hote water at eche remewyng v. pater noster in worchep of .v woundes þat crist suffird for all sinful men

msItem.title: Method for ascertaining whether a sick man shall live or die
msItem.rubric: 155 To knowe weþer a seke man schal dye or noon
msItem.incipit: 155 Say þeis wordes before is bed wan he slepes Ancorea pancorene and if he here hem he schal lywe and if he here hem not he schal dye

msItem.title: Medical and dietary advice for the four seasons of the year
msItem.incipit: 170 Here begynnyþ þe .7. ende of feuerer and enduryþ to þe .7. ende of may
msItem.explicit: 173 and þese þinges abatyt þe superfluwyte of malencoly

msItem.title: Canicular days
msItem.incipit: 173 Caniculares and ferþer more þer ben somere dayes caniculares in þe wheche is grette perel to take dryinkes oþer for to be lete blod
msItem.explicit: 176 In december ete þu well all gode metes and drynkes well alle gode drynkes and lete þe blod and þe nede and ete lekes and coles in wortes and kepe þe welle from cold and from surfettis for it is perel to ketche colde in surfettyng for þe dropesy

msItem.title: Herbal
msItem.incipit: 176 The virtu of beteyne: Beteyne is as herbe of many uirtuys qwat manere of man þat beres beten up on hym þer schall no manere venomys best doo hym any harme whil he beryt it
msItem.explicit: 177-178 and it schal slake þeache vnder þe sydys and of þe wombe of þe stomak and for þe dropsye and for þe palsy and for þe hedache

msItem.title: Recipe to remove freckles
msItem.incipit: 178 For to doun awey frekeles in a mannys face or on a mannys hondys. Take þe blod of an hare or þe blod of a bole and anoynte þe face þer þe frekeles ben and it schal distrie hem for serteyne

msItem.title: Tract on the four human body parts that are subject to disease
msItem.rubric: 178 Her ben þe .4. partyes of a man
msItem.incipit: 178 Here ben þe .4. partyes of a man in þe wheche and a man takit rapest greuaunce and sekenesse þat is to wete in þe hede or in þe brest on in wombe or in þe bledder and be þese tokenes aftir wretyn þu schalt knowe in what euel in a mannys body he is most grewyd
msItem.explicit: 181 And also þe juse of purge on englische dowisfecte and sopes gras soþen in wyn and hoso husit noȝt þese medycyn þer sewiþ hastyly þe dropsey and dropik or chawfyd in þe leuere or þe entrales stoppit or he schal haue þe stoun

msItem.title: Prognostic method for determining whether a patient will live or die
msItem.rubric: 181 ffor to wete ȝif a man schall dye or leue
msItem.incipit: 181 For to wete ȝif a man schal dye or leue. Take an egge þat his leyde þe same day of an henne and wryte þeron þese lettres .ȝ. f. g. f. y. z. x. g. y. s. þanne ley þin egge hundir hym in a faste place al nyȝte and ȝif þer be blod wiþ inne he schal dye and ȝif þer be non he schal leue. Si uis ut appariet uel in sompnorem tuam furat scribeas litteras in pargamino et pone sub capite quando vadis ad lectum tuum

msItem.title: Tract on the urines of women [excerpt from 'Urina Rufa']
msItem.incipit: 183 V[r]yne of hem þat ben wiþ chyld ȝif þei agon a moneþ or .ij. or .3. it schal be ful clere and it schal haue a whyte ypostasye in þe grounde
msItem.explicit: 181 moystenes is cause of colour of þikke substaunce

msItem.title: Cleansing of Blood
msItem.incipit: 183 Huryne is deuidid: Huyrine is deuidid in .4. perties
msItem.explicit: 184 it is ful of lytil stones and oþer while þe recedens is þikke and þenne but it be by hurynys expulciones of venomouse mater it is sygne of deþ

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 184 A medicynes for colowr: A medicinez for colour of chaunilez flesch avente þe in þe leggis huse þe crope of sange and drinke triasandaly
msItem.explicit: 187 Glauca medicyne: Glauca medicine .Recipe. Juse of tansey þe rede worte boyle hem in wyn wiþ alitill honey and use it

msItem.title: Tractatus de morbo epidemiae [Shorter version] [English translation]
msItem.author: John of Burgundy
msItem.incipit: 187 The .1. capittellus how man schal kepe hym in tyme þerof. The 2. sekenesse comes. The 3. qwat meycines aȝens it is
msItem.explicit: 192 And loke þat þu ordeyne þese þinges þat þo be forseyde for to make poundir. And drede þe neuere þe pestelence.

msItem.title: Added note on the manuscript
msItem.incipit: 192 this book is 104 leves
msItem.note: The note, if correct, suggests that a quire of eight leaves (a quaternion) is missing from the manuscript as it was in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the cough
msItem.incipit: 192 ffor the cowhe and for to breke fleme: Take fenell annes sugarcandy lycores nuttemugges and a few greyns breke them yn a brasyn morter togeder and syfte them thorowe a fyne syve of of here
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

foliation.p: Early modern (17th- or 18th-century) pagination with modern foliation of the flyleaves:
foliation.note: Numbering in black ink in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos in the hand of Daniel Waterland (1683-1740), Master of Magdalene College; except for the numbers 'i' (pastedown on the inside of the upper cover), 'ii', 'iii', and 'iv' that have been written in pencil on the paper pastedown on the inside of the upper cover and flyleaves at the beginningby a modern hand (f. [v] is an unfoliated flyleaf that follows f. iv).

catchwords.seg: Catchwords visible in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of some quires (pp. 36, 54, 74, 90, 106)

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and line ruling. Mainly single columns, except pp. 113-116 which have three columns. Usually 27 lines to the page, but sometimes 29 or 31, written below top line.

handNote.p: pp. 1-38 and pp. 42-192 have been copied by one scribe in an Anglicana Formata occasionally written more cursively. It appears that the scribe worked on this manuscript over a longer period of time.
pp. 39-41 have been copied by a scribe working in a small cursive hand with both Secretary and Anglicana features.
pp. 110-142 are a palimpsest. They feature a fourteenth-century liturgical text in Gothic textura that has been largely washed off to create blank leaves for this manuscript.

decoNote.p: Small and large (1-2 lines) plain red initials.
1 large (3 line) red initial with penwork decoration in black ink inside the letter and pen-flourishing in black ink extending into the margin on p. 108.

additions.note: Marginal additions to medical treatises and recipes in 15th-, 16th- and possibly early 17th-century hands. These usually concern the names of recipes or their ingredients, but there are two longer additions: an astrological note in the lower margin of p. 16: because the time is very neare exactly knowne how longe a woman goeth from þe time of conception: yf it be knowne in what moneth a man is borne and what signe, by counting backward the time of a womans aging, ye may count þe moneth [...]; and a lists of humours and planets and their relationship to organs in the human body in the lower margin of p. 111. Both texts were probably added in the 16th century.

note.p: Note of the manuscript's contents and a table of contents by of Daniel Waterland (1683-1740), Master of Magdalene College, on on p. iii recto.
Quire numbers in pencil in the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires added by a modern hand.

binding.p: 17th-century mottled brown calf with a blank coat of arms inscribed with the name of Samuel Peppys on the front cover, and Pepys' coat of arms gold-stamped on the rear cover; red-speckled edges.

origin.origDate: Copied in the first half of the 15th century.

history.provenance: Acquired before 1700 by Samuel Pepys (1633–1703), naval officer and diarist Pepys, Samuel, 1633-1703; no. 6802.83 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697); f. iii verso features an engraving of his portrait with the motto: 'Mens cujusque is est Quisque' and 'Sam. Pepys. Car. et. Iac. Angl. Regib. A. Secretis. Admiraliae' by R. White ['R. W. sculp.'], c. 1690 ; f. iv recto a paper pastedown with Pepys's bookplate engraved with two anchors and the motto 'Mens cujusque is est Quisque'.

acquisition.p: Acquired by Magdalene College, Cambridge upon the death of John Jackson (d. 1724) Jackson, John, d. 1724 : in his will (The National Archives, PROB 1/9, Will of Samuel Pepys, Codicil, 13th May 1703), Pepys left a bequest of approximately 3000 manuscripts and printed books to Magdalene College and instructed his nephew John Jackson to arrange for this but they only came to the college after Jackson died. Jackson respected the instructions given in the codicil to the will as can be evidenced from Magdalene College Archives A/41/1: an indenture between Anne Jackson, widow and executrix of John Jackson (nephew and residuary legatee of Samuel Pepys), and the Master and Fellows being a deed of covenant as to providing a Library at the College for the reception of the collection of the books and papers bequeathed to the College by Samuel Pepys, 1 June 1724. It is here that the manuscript's current shelfmark 'No 878' was inscribed in red ink on the inside of the front cover (p. i).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936 A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the College Library of Magdalene College, Cambridge (London: Sidgwick and Jackson, 1914) and the Catalogue of the Pepys Library at Magdalene College Cambridge, Volume V: Manuscripts, Part I: Medieval, compiled by Rosamond McKitterick and Richard Beadle (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1992), by kind permission of the Boydell Press.

availability.p: Visitors to Magdalene College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Pepys Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Magdalene College: Pepys Library.
